awd_titl_txt: Nanoscale Structure and Dynamics of Chromatin
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this research is to advance fundamental understanding of the structure and assembly of centromeres, the specialized segments of chromosomes that allow them to separate accurately during cell division.  The project will take advantage of cutting-edge molecular biophysics approaches to probe key differences in the organization of centromeres, relative to other parts of chromosomes. Scientific and technological advances will be integrated into hands-on research training for undergraduate and graduate students and will be incorporated into a formal course of study in structural biology and biophysics. Application of state-of-the art technology to central questions in chromosome biology is expected not only to inspire student interest in basic science, but also to prepare them for careers at the interface of biology and physics. 

In eukaryotic cells, accurate segregation of replicated chromosomes during cell division is mediated by centromeres.  If centromeres become damaged or removed, chromosomes segregate randomly, thus disrupting the cell division process. Centromeres differ from the rest of the chromosomes by containing nucleosomes (DNA-protein building blocks of higher-order chromatin) in which the typical protein histone H3 has been replaced by a related histone known as CENP-A. This replacement is presumed to confer new structural organization to the centromere, thereby enabling it to be recognized by the segregation machinery. However, details about the structure and the mechanism underlying the highly specific recognition remain uncertain. The studies in this project are designed to advance knowledge of centromere chromatin structure at all levels of its organization and especially to understand what structural features distinguish centromeres from non-centromeric regions of chromosomes. High-resolution atomic force microscopy (AFM) studies will be used to assess the structure of centromere chromatin at different levels of organization. Single nucleosomes and nucleosome arrays will be visualized directly with the use of cutting-edge high-speed AFM, enabling dynamic imaging in aqueous solution at nanoscale with video-rate temporal resolution. The experimental data will be supplemented by high-power computational analysis. This combined approach will shed new light on the structure and dynamics of centromere nucleosomes and nucleosome arrays and will lead to understanding the relationship between centromere structure and its function during the chromosomal segregation process.  

This project is co-funded by the Genetic Mechanisms Program in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences and by the Emerging Frontiers Division, both in the Biological Sciences Directorate, and by the Physics of Living Systems Program in the Physics Division in the Mathematical and Physical Sciences Directorate.

por.por_cntn:
Chromatin integrity is crucial for normal cell development. The cell division process is accompanied by the segregation of replicated chromosome, and chromatin centromeres, specialized segments of chromosomes provide the accuracy of the chromosomal segregation. If the centromere becomes damaged or removed, chromosomes segregate randomly disrupting the cell division process. The centromeres are specifically recognized by kinetochores suggesting that centromeres contain specific structural characteristics. However, these structural details and the mechanism underlying their highly specific recognition remain uncertain. The studies in this project are expected to advance the knowledge of centromere chromatin structure at all levels of its organization and specifically to understand what structural features distinguish centromeres from other regions of chromosomes. This fundamental research topic will inspire students’ interest to basic science. Additionally, the cutting-edge single molecule biophysics techniques are applied in the project that constitute another attractive component of the project for the students at different levels. We discovered that centromere nucleosomes are underwrapped compared with the regular ones. Moreover, centromere nucleosomes utilize different pathways for the disassembly. Another novel finding was the high stability of the centromere nucleosome cores allowing for the nucleosome to transfer over the large distances on DNA. Importantly, we detected the transfer of the nucleosome core from one DNA to another. We were able to directly visualize by AFM this process, which is another unique property of centromere chromatin. Another discovery was on the role of the DNA sequence on interaction between the nucleosomes. We found that nucleosomes do interact with each other, and this interaction does not depend on such an important geometrical nucleosome characteristic as the wrapping efficiency that defines the orientation of one nucleosome relative to another. This finding suggests that other factors, not related to DNA, define the interactions between the nucleosomes. We hypothesize that a critical component is the role of histone tails that are known to contribute to inter-nucleosome interactions and have been shown to stabilize a nucleosome’s position. This hypothesis will be tested in the renewal application.   

 

Broader impact

Opportunities for training and professional development.

This project was made primarily by students, starting with graduate student Micah Stumme-Diers, a biochemistry major from Western Washington University. He initially joined our lab as a visiting summer student; after training in the laboratory of our collaborator, Dr. Yamini Dalal (NIH), he became a graduate student. A graduate student in the lab, Yaqing Wang, contributed to the AFM studies of nucleosomes arrays with her high skill in AFM imaging of protein-DNA complexes. The chromatin project was interesting to a number of undergraduate students from the University of Nebraska Omaha (UNO). UNO student William Bakke, who majored in physics, worked in the summer of 2016. Two more UNO students, Thomas Stormberg and Shaun Filliaux, continued the research as interns after the summer semesters of 2017 and 2018, and joined the lab in 2019 as graduate students. Undergraduate Nicholas Hohensee worked on the project during the summer of 2018, very successfully presented his research at the 5th Single Molecule Workshop, Ames, IA (2018), and is currently a UNMC professional pharmacy student. 

Dissemination of the results to communities of interest.

The PI, students, and postdocs presented the results of this project at various international, national, and local meetings. The PI made presentations as a keynote speaker at the international Structural Biology 2017 meeting in Zurich, Switzerland and at the 10thStructural Biology 2018, Berlin, Germany; he was a plenary speaker at the meeting “Interacting Proteins as Single Molecules - In Vitro and In Vivo”, Cancun, Mexico (2018) and as invited speaker at a workshop “Protein-DNA Interactions: from Biophysics to Cancer Biology” in December 2019 at the M. D. Anderson Medical Center-Rice University, Houston, USA. Micah Stumme-Diers at the 7thStructural Biology and Molecular Biophysics Workshop, Omaha, NE got the first place in the poster competition. He presented the work on dynamics of CENP-A nucleosome as an oral presentation at the 5th Single Molecule Workshop, Ames, IA (2018). Undergraduate Nicholas Hohensee presented a poster on CENP-A dinucleosomes at the same 5th Single Molecule Workshop. Tommy Stormberg was awarded for a poster on the nucleosome interaction at the 8th Workshop in Structural Biology and Molecular Biophysics, Omaha, NE (August 15, 2019). We have been invited by JoVE Video Journal to publish video of our protocol for the AFM studies of chromatin. This 2019 publication was very successful and we have recently received another invitation from the JoVE editors. Note as well the 2018 publication in Methods in Molecular Biology (1814, 225-242) entitled: “Assembly of Centromere Chromatin for Characterization by High-Speed Time-Lapse Atomic Force Microscopy”.

Other labs have contacted us to learn about our advances in chromatin studies, for example, Karolyn Luger, HHMI investigator at University of Boulder, CO.
